Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Endovascular Versus Open Surgical Treatment for Isolated Popliteal Artery Lesions

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either EVT or open surgery.

Participants.evidence: Eligible participants included patients with isolated PA lesions, excluding those with aneurysms or traumatic injuries.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either EVT or open surgery.

Objective.evidence: This study compares the efficacy and safety of endovascular treatment (EVT) versus open surgical interventions for isolated PA lesions.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was primary patency at 12 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not feasible due to the nature of the interventions.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the EVT group and 100 to the open surgery group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis, with 98 participants in the EVT group and 97 in the open surgery group analysed.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The primary patency rate at 12 months was 71.7% in the EVT group and 75.6% in the open surgery group (p = 0.510).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events occurred in 3% of the EVT group and 1% of the open surgery group, with mild severity.

Funding.evidence: This study was supported by institutional research grants.
